5 ways to keep your kids entertained at home during coronavirus outbreak | YorkRegion.com 5 ways to keep your kids entertained at home during coronavirus outbreak News Apr 12, 2020 by Aileen Zangouei YorkRegion.com As all schools are temporarily closed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, you may be feeling that you and your kids are running out of ideas for fun things to do in your home. Here's a list of a few things you can do from your home, and the best part is, they're all super fun: Canada's Wonderland has virtual rides of all sorts on their website that you can experience from your very own home. No long lineups, no tickets, just go to the website, click play, and choose which ride you want to experience from your home. It's that easy, and it's fun. Crock A Doodle's Whitchurch-Stouffville location is helping kids paint at home by lending their paints and brushed with free delivery to your home. You just have to pay for the pottery pieces you select. Visit their Facebook page, or call them at 905-640-1284 for more information. Latcham Art Centre will post your art on their virtual community sketchbook if you send it in to them. You can also join them for a virtual tour of their exhibition. McMichael Canadian Art Collection can be visited online. Also, ArtVenture Online is being offered to help you stay connected with the McMichael collection. Educators and artists are offering art activities, videos, tutorials and more from home. Virtual Kids Cooking Classes offered by the Chef Upstairs. Their very first virtual class for kids will run from 10 a.m. to noon and the kids will be prepare a full meal with the guidance of a chef and parental supervision at home. Registration is required. 5 ways to keep your kids entertained at home during coronavirus outbreak Online cooking classes, Canada's Wonderland's virtual rides, and more. Watch out for these coronavirus-related scams, OPP warns | YorkRegion.com Watch out for these COVID-19 related scams, OPP warns News Apr 15, 2020 by Veronica Appia YorkRegion.com The Ontario Provincial Police and Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre (CAFC) are warning Ontarians to beware of scammers preying on those who are fearful of COVID-19 to steal their money and personal information. Police say these fraudsters tend to fabricate an urgent, health-related scenario when contacting their victim — similar to most other cyber scams — in an effort to pressure that person into providing them with funds or information as quickly as possible. The CAFC has compiled a list of the most common types of scams that have been circulating, many of which involve fraudsters pretending to be from reputable companies or organizations. These include: • Fraudulent calls from companies offering duct cleaning services or air filters to protect from COVID-19 • Hydro companies threatening to cut off power for nonpayment • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention or the World Health Organization selling lists of nearby residents who have contracted the virus • Public Health Agency of Canada providing test results in return for personal information • Charities offering personal protective equipment in exchange for a donation • Companies selling rapid COVID-19 tests and more These scams take many forms including phone calls, text messages and emails. The CAFC is reminding residents that fraudsters can also spoof their phone numbers and emails to make them appear as though coming from genuine organizations. Has this happened to you? If you think you have been scammed, there are some steps you can take. If the interaction happened on a computer, running anti-virus software or speaking to a trusted computer technician may help get rid of any viruses or malware, the OPP said. The centre also recommends changing your passwords, as the scammer may have accessed them during the interaction. If you have provided any financial information to the fraudster, the OPP recommends contacting your banking institution immediately. Pandemic planting: Online resources for vegetable gardeners | YorkRegion.com Pandemic planting: Online resources for vegetable gardeners News May 01, 2020 by Lee Ann Waterman YorkRegion.com First-timers and seasoned gardeners alike have embraced “pandemic planting” in recent weeks. Here are a few resources to help you nurture your vegetables through the next few months and ensure a bountiful harvest. YOU GROW GIRL Toronto resident Gayla Trail has been writing about small space gardening for 20 years, on her blog and in a slew of books. You’ll find loads of tips for growing in containers and city lots — with a resourceful, do-it-yourself bent. SAVVY GARDENING This site features wide-ranging advice from three gardening experts — including Halifax author Niki Jabbour, whose book “The Year-Round Vegetable Gardener” is an inspiration for anyone who dreams of home-grown tomatoes in February. ONTARIO MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE, FOOD AND RURAL AFFAIRS Although designed for commercial growers, this site offers a wealth of practical information for the home gardener, too — from what bugs might eat your bok choy to how to prune your pear tree. MARK CULLEN One of Canada’s best-known gardening experts and writers, Mark Cullen offers straightforward answers to 10,000 questions on edible and ornamental gardens, lawns and landscaping, as well as a free monthly newsletter. PUNK DOMESTICS For hundreds of community-sourced recipes for preserving your harvest — from drying and dehydrating to pickling and fermenting, look for Punk Domestics on Facebook or Instagram or search their archived website.
